summary: The Supreme Court has upheld the acquittal of a man by the High Court of Bombay in a case of dishonoured cheques. summary: The Punjab and Haryana High Court has ruled that the Sub Fire Officers of the Punjab State Electricity Board are entitled to the same pay scale as those of other posts. The appellant-Board filed a writ petition in the High Court of Punjab claiming that the pay scale of the respondents-Sub Fire Officers is less than the State Government employees. The respondents in this appeal have rightly contended that the post of Sub Fire Officers is categorised in Group XII and accordingly, the pay scale of Sub Fire Officers is not equal to the pay scale of Head Clerks, Head Clerk-cum-Divisional Accountants, Internal Auditors, etc. The following points arise for consideration in this appeal:- (i) Whether Sub Fire Officers can claim parity of pay scale with pay scale of Head Clerks, Head Clerk-cum-Divisional Accountants, Internal Auditors, etc.

summary: The Supreme Court of India is hearing two petitions challenging the constitutional validity of various provisions of the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code, 2016. Shri Mukul Rohatgi assailed the provisions of the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code of India (the Code) on the ground that it is discriminatory and manifestly arbitrary in that operational creditors do not have even a single vote in the committee of creditors which has very important functions to perform in the resolution process of corporate debtors. Section 29A of the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code of India is wholly arbitrary and without any basis in law.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has disposed of three writ petitions challenging certain provisions of the Maharashtra Prohibition of Obscene Dance in Hotels,Restaurants and Rooms and Protection of Dignity of Women (Working therein) Rules, 2016. The petitioners have been granted valid licences under the provisions of the said Entertainment Rules and Amusement Rules and have been carrying on business since the past several years and their licences have been renewed from time to time. The Maharashtra Police (Second Amendment) Act, 2014 made it a criminal offence for any person to stage or perform any dance which is obscene within the meaning of Section 294 of the Indian Penal Code and any other law for the time being in force and shall include a dance, - (i) which is designed to arouse prurient interest of the audience and (ii) which consists of a sexual act.

The appellant State and its authorities are directed to extend the benefits of Government Resolution dated 17.10.1988 as ordered by the Supreme Court in order dated 093 passed in case of PWD Employees’ Union (supreme case) to the eligible daily-wage workers of the Forest and Environment Department working for more than five years including those who are performing work other than building maintenance and repairing but they will be entitled for the consequential benefits w.e.f.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has taken up the appeal of the Union of India and others against the judgment and order of the High Court of Gujarat at Ahmedabad, quashing the show cause notices issued by the appellants to their members, in exercise of power under 73(1) of the Finance Act, 1994 (for short, ‘the Finance Act’). The appellants have challenged the show cause notices issued by the Central Board of Excise and Customs (CBEC) to them under the provisions of Finance Act, 1994 and the circulars issued by the CBEC itself from time to time. In this case, the appellants have challenged the validity of the circulars issued by the Central Board of Indirect Taxes and Customs (CBIC) and the Income Tax Department (ITDC) on the ground that they were not applicable prior to the amendment in the parent Act, 2008.

summary: The Supreme Court of India is hearing an appeal by the Union of India against a lower court's decision to dismiss its petition challenging the constitutional validity of Aadhaar. The Supreme Court of India has reserved its verdict on the plea of the All India Tennis Federation (AITF) challenging the decision of the Delhi High Court to dismiss its petition challenging the constitutional validity of the Delhi High Court's order allowing the All India Tennis Federation (AITF) to field its players in the Delhi High Court tennis tournament. The Supreme Court has granted leave to the Union of India to appeal against the view of the Punjab and Haryana High Court which is that the non-grant of solatium and interest to lands acquired under the Union Of India vs Tarsem Singh on 19 September, 2019 Indian Kanoon - http://indiankanoon.org/doc/92512441/ 3National Highways Act, which is available if lands are acquired under the Land Acquisition Act, is bad in law, and consequently that Section 3J of the National Highways Act, 1956 be struck down as being violative of Article 14 of the Constitution of India to this extent.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that a bank can not pay ex-gratia to employees who have died. The Supreme Court of India has ruled that the dependants of employees, who die in harness, do not have any special claim or right to employment, except by way of the concession that may be extended by the employer under the rules or by a separate scheme, to enable the family of the deceased to get over the sudden financial crisis. The Supreme Court of India has set aside the impugned judgments of the Delhi High Court on the issue of compassionate appointment.

summary: The appellant has appealed against the verdict of the Madhya Pradesh High Court which sentenced him to three-and-a-half years in jail for offences under the Indian Penal Code (IPC). summary: The Supreme Court has set aside an order passed by the High Court of Calcutta on 136 in two separate petitions filed by the respondent against two tenants. Section 7(2) of the Premises (Control of Rent and Eviction) Act, 1950 provides that a tenant who fails to make an application under the Act within a period of three months from the date of commencement of the tenancy, will be liable to be evicted. The Supreme Court of India has held that the West Bengal Rent Control Ordinance, 1968, which came into force on 1 January 1969, provided for the protection of tenants who were in default in paying rent.

summary: The appellant has moved the National Green Tribunal (NGT) against the order of the Principal Bench of the NGT dismissing his grievance against allotment of local ponds to private industrialists. The appellant filed an application before the National Green Tribunal (NGT) against the setting up of a cement factory by the Gujarat National Industrial Development Agency (GNIDA) in the ecologically sensitive area of Aravali in Gujarat. The appellant, Sharp, had been given the land by the Gram Panchayat as part of the industrial development project of the Greater Noida Industrial Development Agency (GNIDA), but it was not registered as a ‘pokhar’ in the revenue records of GNIDA and it was not integrated in the project.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that the Calcutta Club Limited (CCL) is not entitled to a licence to operate as a sports club in the state of West Bengal. The Supreme Court of India has taken up an appeal by Calcutta Club Limited against a decision of the West Bengal State Tax Tribunal that it was not liable to pay sales tax on the supply of food and drinks to its permanent members. The Court of Appeal for the State of West Bengal has held that the Calcutta Club is not eligible to tax under the West Bengal Sales Tax Act, 1994 (hereinafter referred to as the “Act“) as it sells products to the non-members or guests who accompany the permanent members, but when the invoices are raised in respect of supply made in favour of the permanent members, no sales tax is collected.

summary: Appeal by Uttam Ram against an order passed by the High Court of Himachal Pradesh which dismissed his complaint under the Himachal Pradesh Shops and Establishments Act, 1881. In the cross-examination conducted by the respondent, CW3 Prem Chand deposed that the appellant had to recover an amount of Rs.7,86,300/- and after adjustment of Rs.2,47,444/- the balance amount was payable by the respondent for which the settlement was arrived in his presence when cheque No. 942816 was issued for a sum of Rs.5,38,856/- dated 21. The Supreme Court has held that a cheque is presumed to be for consideration unless and until, the Court forms a belief that the consideration does not exist or considers the non-existence of consideration was so probable that a prudent man would under no circumstances of the case, act upon the plea that the consideration does not exist.

summary: The Supreme Court has upheld the conviction and death sentence of a man for the rape and murder of an eight-year-old girl in Bihar in 2011. The petitioner Abdul Mannan was convicted and sentenced to death by the Fast Track Court at Muzaffarpur, Bihar, for the offences of rape, kidnapping, robbery and criminal conspiracy. The Court of Appeal in Bachan Singh has held that death sentence cannot be inflicted on the appellant since the dictum of the Constitution Bench in Bachan Singh is that the legislative policy in Section 354(3) of the 1973 Code is that for a person convicted of murder, life imprisonment is the rule and death sentence, an exception, and the mitigating circumstances must be given due consideration.
